issue.title: V2.6.0 update to openssl v3.1.4
V2.6.0 update to openssl v3.1.4
Custom weights are lost when mysql_galera_hostgroups is in use
issue.body:
- ProxySQL version 2.5.5
- OS version Centos 7.9
- Steps to reproduce the issue:

1) Populate servers and galera_hostgroups:
```
proxysql> INSERT INTO mysql_servers
    ->   (hostgroup_id, hostname, weight, use_ssl) VALUES
    ->   (2, 'mysql3', 1000, 1),
    ->   (3, 'mysql1', 1000, 1),
    ->   (3, 'mysql2', 1000, 1),
    ->   (3, 'mysql3', 1000, 1),
    ->   (4, 'mysql1', 1000, 1),
    ->   (4, 'mysql2', 1000, 1);
Query OK, 6 rows affected (0.00 sec)

proxysql> INSERT INTO mysql_galera_hostgroups (writer_hostgroup, backup_writer_hostgroup, reader_hostgroup, offline_hostgroup, active, max_writers, writer_is_also_reader, max_transactions_behind) VALUES (2, 4, 3, 1, 1, 1, 1, 100);
```

2) Check mysql_servers at runtime:
```
proxysql> select hostgroup_id, hostname, weight from runtime_mysql_servers;
+--------------+----------+--------+
| hostgroup_id | hostname | weight |
+--------------+----------+--------+
| 2            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 2            | mysql2   | 1000   |
| 2            | mysql3   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql2   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql3   | 1000   |
| 4            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 4            | mysql2   | 1000   |
+--------------+----------+--------+
8 rows in set (0.00 sec)
```

- Now let's try changing the weight of a server:
```
proxysql> update mysql_servers set weight=1 where hostgroup_id = 3 and hostname = 'mysql2';
Query OK, 1 row affected (0.00 sec)

proxysql> select hostgroup_id, hostname, weight from mysql_servers;
+--------------+----------+--------+
| hostgroup_id | hostname | weight |
+--------------+----------+--------+
| 2            | mysql3   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql2   | 1      |
| 3            | mysql3   | 1000   |
| 4            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 4            | mysql2   | 1000   |
+--------------+----------+--------+
6 rows in set (0.00 sec)

proxysql> load mysql servers to runtime; save mysql servers to disk;
Query OK, 0 rows affected (0.01 sec)

Query OK, 0 rows affected (0.03 sec)
```

- See that the weight has changed:
```
proxysql> select hostgroup_id, hostname, weight from runtime_mysql_servers;
+--------------+----------+--------+
| hostgroup_id | hostname | weight |
+--------------+----------+--------+
| 2            | mysql3   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql2   | 1      |
| 3            | mysql3   | 1000   |
| 4            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 4            | mysql2   | 1000   |
+--------------+----------+--------+
6 rows in set (0.00 sec)
```
- Now repeat the query a few seconds later, the weight is back to 1000
```
proxysql> select hostgroup_id, hostname, weight from runtime_mysql_servers;
+--------------+----------+--------+
| hostgroup_id | hostname | weight |
+--------------+----------+--------+
| 2            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 2            | mysql2   | 1000   |
| 2            | mysql3   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql2   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql3   | 1000   |
| 4            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 4            | mysql2   | 1000   |
+--------------+----------+--------+
8 rows in set (0.01 sec)
```

If we empty mysql_galera_hostgroups table and repeat the test, the weight is not affected.

comment.body: Understood Rene, let me know if I can provide anything else to shed some light into this. Thanks!

issue.title: Custom weights are lost when mysql_galera_hostgroups is in use
issue.body:
- ProxySQL version 2.5.5
- OS version Centos 7.9
- Steps to reproduce the issue:

1) Populate servers and galera_hostgroups:

| 3            | mysql2   | 1000   |

- Now let's try changing the weight of a server:
```
proxysql> update mysql_servers set weight=1 where hostgroup_id = 3 and hostname = 'mysql2';

proxysql> select hostgroup_id, hostname, weight from mysql_servers;

| 3            | mysql3   | 1000   |

+--------------+----------+--------+

proxysql> load mysql servers to runtime; save mysql servers to disk;

- See that the weight has changed:
```
proxysql> select hostgroup_id, hostname, weight from runtime_mysql_servers;
+--------------+----------+--------+
| hostgroup_id | hostname | weight |
+--------------+----------+--------+
| 2            | mysql3   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql2   | 1      |
| 3            | mysql3   | 1000   |
| 4            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 4            | mysql2   | 1000   |
+--------------+----------+--------+
6 rows in set (0.00 sec)

- Now repeat the query a few seconds later, the weight is back to 1000
```
proxysql> select hostgroup_id, hostname, weight from runtime_mysql_servers;
+--------------+----------+--------+
| hostgroup_id | hostname | weight |
+--------------+----------+--------+
| 2            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 2            | mysql2   | 1000   |
| 2            | mysql3   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql2   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql3   | 1000   |
| 4            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 4            | mysql2   | 1000   |
+--------------+----------+--------+
8 rows in set (0.01 sec)
```

If we empty mysql_galera_hostgroups table and repeat the test, the weight is not affected.

comment.body:
This line tricked me:
```
2023-10-25 17:15:42 MySQL_HostGroups_Manager.cpp:6197:update_galera_set_writer(): [WARNING] Galera: setting host mysql2:3306 as writer
```
I initially assumed that `mysql2` is the right writer, but after carefully reading the rest of the log I see that the server is than shunned in hostgroup 2 .
Therefore I must apologize: there was no incorrect configuration being loaded. My bad.

"Losing" the weight is expected if `mysql2` was the right writer.
Now we need to verify why `update_galera_set_writer()` tried to bring `mysql2` to the writer_hostgroup . This is probably a more complicated issue that just a lost `weight`

proxysql> load mysql servers to runtime; save mysql servers to disk;

proxysql> select hostgroup_id, hostname, weight from runtime_mysql_servers;

| 4            | mysql2   | 1000   |

| hostgroup_id | hostname | weight |
+--------------+----------+--------+

```

If we empty mysql_galera_hostgroups table and repeat the test, the weight is not affected.

comment.body: Hi Rene, thanks for revieweing the logs. I don't understand what is the incorrect/conflicting configuration. We are starting from a "good configuration" where mysql3 is the writer and only changing the weight of one of the readers (mysql2). Can you clarify?

issue.title: Custom weights are lost when mysql_galera_hostgroups is in use
issue.body:
- ProxySQL version 2.5.5
- OS version Centos 7.9
- Steps to reproduce the issue:

1) Populate servers and galera_hostgroups:
```
proxysql> INSERT INTO mysql_servers
    ->   (hostgroup_id, hostname, weight, use_ssl) VALUES
    ->   (2, 'mysql3', 1000, 1),
    ->   (3, 'mysql1', 1000, 1),
    ->   (3, 'mysql2', 1000, 1),
    ->   (3, 'mysql3', 1000, 1),
    ->   (4, 'mysql1', 1000, 1),
    ->   (4, 'mysql2', 1000, 1);
Query OK, 6 rows affected (0.00 sec)

proxysql> INSERT INTO mysql_galera_hostgroups (writer_hostgroup, backup_writer_hostgroup, reader_hostgroup, offline_hostgroup, active, max_writers, writer_is_also_reader, max_transactions_behind) VALUES (2, 4, 3, 1, 1, 1, 1, 100);
```

2) Check mysql_servers at runtime:
```
proxysql> select hostgroup_id, hostname, weight from runtime_mysql_servers;
+--------------+----------+--------+
| hostgroup_id | hostname | weight |
+--------------+----------+--------+
| 2            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 2            | mysql2   | 1000   |
| 2            | mysql3   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql2   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql3   | 1000   |
| 4            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 4            | mysql2   | 1000   |
+--------------+----------+--------+
8 rows in set (0.00 sec)
```

- Now let's try changing the weight of a server:
```
proxysql> update mysql_servers set weight=1 where hostgroup_id = 3 and hostname = 'mysql2';
Query OK, 1 row affected (0.00 sec)

proxysql> select hostgroup_id, hostname, weight from mysql_servers;
+--------------+----------+--------+
| hostgroup_id | hostname | weight |
+--------------+----------+--------+
| 2            | mysql3   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql2   | 1      |
| 3            | mysql3   | 1000   |
| 4            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 4            | mysql2   | 1000   |
+--------------+----------+--------+
6 rows in set (0.00 sec)

proxysql> load mysql servers to runtime; save mysql servers to disk;
Query OK, 0 rows affected (0.01 sec)

Query OK, 0 rows affected (0.03 sec)
```

- See that the weight has changed:
```
proxysql> select hostgroup_id, hostname, weight from runtime_mysql_servers;
+--------------+----------+--------+
| hostgroup_id | hostname | weight |
+--------------+----------+--------+
| 2            | mysql3   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql2   | 1      |
| 3            | mysql3   | 1000   |
| 4            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 4            | mysql2   | 1000   |
+--------------+----------+--------+
6 rows in set (0.00 sec)
```
- Now repeat the query a few seconds later, the weight is back to 1000
```
proxysql> select hostgroup_id, hostname, weight from runtime_mysql_servers;
+--------------+----------+--------+
| hostgroup_id | hostname | weight |
+--------------+----------+--------+
| 2            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 2            | mysql2   | 1000   |
| 2            | mysql3   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql2   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql3   | 1000   |
| 4            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 4            | mysql2   | 1000   |
+--------------+----------+--------+
8 rows in set (0.01 sec)
```

If we empty mysql_galera_hostgroups table and repeat the test, the weight is not affected.

comment.body:
Ok, so what I see now is that an incorrect/conflicting configuration was loaded.
In fact, after the `UPDATE` + `load mysql servers to runtime` , it was asked to ProxySQL to remove `mysql2` from the writer_hostgroup (2) .
Monitor then promoted `mysql2` from hostgroup 4 (`backup_writer_hostgroup`) to hostgroup 2 (`writer_hostgroup`) .
Then, according to `writer_is_also_reader=1` , `mysql2` was copied from `writer_hostgroup` to `reader_hostgroup` .
`mysql2` in hostgroup 2 has `weight=1000` , and it is copied to hostgroup 2 with `weight=1000` .

Again: this is triggered by loading an incorrect/conflicting configuration.

This is expected

issue.title: Custom weights are lost when mysql_galera_hostgroups is in use
issue.body:
- ProxySQL version 2.5.5
- OS version Centos 7.9
- Steps to reproduce the issue:

1) Populate servers and galera_hostgroups:
```

issue.title: V2.6.0 update to openssl v3.1.4
V2.6.0 more makefile fixes
V2.x tap tests optional ssl and compression via env variables
issue.body:
modify capable TAP tests to run in a matrix
usessl: [ 'none', 'client', 'server', 'both' ]
to exercise all kinds of connections

add matrix dimension compression
compress: [ 'none', 'client', 'server', 'both' ]

issue.title: Feature Request: Query logging to embedded database
issue.body:
Currently, the query logging capabilities of ProxySQL route to a binary file (see #561 ) 

Add option to log to embedded database so that logs can be queried from the ProxySQL admin interface.

comment.body:
Log all queries to file could be a lot of overhead for very busy systems.

Can it support writing all queries to message system, such as kafka

issue.title: ProxySQL 2.5.2 MySQL_HostGroups_Manager.cpp:4614:read_only_action_v2() warning
issue.body:
Hi!

I'm using proxysql on AWS with aurora instances and mysql_aws_aurora_hostgroups / mysql_replication_hostgroups table.

The tables are filled with those values : 

```
INSERT INTO mysql_aws_aurora_hostgroups (writer_hostgroup, reader_hostgroup, active, domain_name, writer_is_also_reader)
VALUES (1, 2, 1, '[prestashop_database_domain_name]', 0);
INSERT INTO mysql_replication_hostgroups (writer_hostgroup, reader_hostgroup, check_type) VALUES (1, 2, 'innodb_read_only');
INSERT INTO mysql_servers (hostgroup_id, hostname, port) VALUES (1, '[prestashop_database_cluster_host]', 3306);
INSERT INTO mysql_servers (hostgroup_id, hostname, port) VALUES (2, '[prestashop_database_ro_cluster_host]', 3306);
```

Since the switch to 2.5.2-217, I'm getting a tons of warnings in the log (one line per seconds) :

2023-05-14 06:29:56 MySQL_HostGroups_Manager.cpp:4614:read_only_action_v2(): [WARNING] Server xxxx.eu-west-1.rds.amazonaws.com:3306 not found 

This server does exist.

It seems the newly refactored readonly code has some issues?

BR,
  Jocelyn Fournier

comment.body:
@renecannao 

I removed `mysql_replication_hostgroups` according to https://github.com/sysown/proxysql/issues/4219#issuecomment-1547001866 and the problem occurred.

### Environment

- ProxySQL2.5.5
  - https://hub.docker.com/layers/proxysql/proxysql/2.5.5/images/sha256-9a0d278abbb57fd6a6ec79e1a24559a71712c8eb68090c54e6859ab584ea7888?context=explore
  - I am using ProxySQL in a k8s environment. Because of this, ProxySQL containers are frequently replaced.

```sql
INSERT INTO mysql_aws_aurora_hostgroups (writer_hostgroup, reader_hostgroup, active, domain_name, writer_is_also_reader)
VALUES (1, 2, 1, '[database_domain_name]', 0);
INSERT INTO mysql_servers (hostgroup_id, hostname, port) VALUES (1, '[database_cluster_host_1]', 3306);
INSERT INTO mysql_servers (hostgroup_id, hostname, port) VALUES (2, '[database_ro_cluster_host_2]', 3306);
```

### Steps to reproduce
1. Add a reader instance in the Aurora MySQL cluster
2. Delete the leader instance added in step 1 in the Aurora MySQL cluster
3. Create a new ProxySQL container or recreate an existing ProxySQL container

In this case, ProxySQL will not start in step 3.

Furthermore, as introduced in https://github.com/sysown/proxysql/issues/2317, the problem did not occur when using `mysql_replication_hostgroups`. (However, the Warning message mentioned in this issue will still appear)

```
INSERT INTO mysql_replication_hostgroups (writer_hostgroup, reader_hostgroup, check_type)
VALUES (1, 2, 'innodb_read_only');
```

issue.title: Custom weights are lost when mysql_galera_hostgroups is in use
issue.body:
- ProxySQL version 2.5.5
- OS version Centos 7.9
- Steps to reproduce the issue:

1) Populate servers and galera_hostgroups:
```
proxysql> INSERT INTO mysql_servers
    ->   (hostgroup_id, hostname, weight, use_ssl) VALUES
    ->   (2, 'mysql3', 1000, 1),
    ->   (3, 'mysql1', 1000, 1),
    ->   (3, 'mysql2', 1000, 1),
    ->   (3, 'mysql3', 1000, 1),
    ->   (4, 'mysql1', 1000, 1),
    ->   (4, 'mysql2', 1000, 1);
Query OK, 6 rows affected (0.00 sec)

proxysql> INSERT INTO mysql_galera_hostgroups (writer_hostgroup, backup_writer_hostgroup, reader_hostgroup, offline_hostgroup, active, max_writers, writer_is_also_reader, max_transactions_behind) VALUES (2, 4, 3, 1, 1, 1, 1, 100);
```

2) Check mysql_servers at runtime:
```
proxysql> select hostgroup_id, hostname, weight from runtime_mysql_servers;
+--------------+----------+--------+
| hostgroup_id | hostname | weight |
+--------------+----------+--------+
| 2            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 2            | mysql2   | 1000   |
| 2            | mysql3   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql2   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql3   | 1000   |
| 4            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 4            | mysql2   | 1000   |
+--------------+----------+--------+
8 rows in set (0.00 sec)
```

- Now let's try changing the weight of a server:
```
proxysql> update mysql_servers set weight=1 where hostgroup_id = 3 and hostname = 'mysql2';
Query OK, 1 row affected (0.00 sec)

proxysql> select hostgroup_id, hostname, weight from mysql_servers;
+--------------+----------+--------+
| hostgroup_id | hostname | weight |
+--------------+----------+--------+
| 2            | mysql3   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql2   | 1      |
| 3            | mysql3   | 1000   |
| 4            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 4            | mysql2   | 1000   |
+--------------+----------+--------+
6 rows in set (0.00 sec)

proxysql> load mysql servers to runtime; save mysql servers to disk;
Query OK, 0 rows affected (0.01 sec)

Query OK, 0 rows affected (0.03 sec)
```

- See that the weight has changed:
```
proxysql> select hostgroup_id, hostname, weight from runtime_mysql_servers;
+--------------+----------+--------+
| hostgroup_id | hostname | weight |
+--------------+----------+--------+
| 2            | mysql3   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql2   | 1      |
| 3            | mysql3   | 1000   |
| 4            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 4            | mysql2   | 1000   |
+--------------+----------+--------+
6 rows in set (0.00 sec)
```
- Now repeat the query a few seconds later, the weight is back to 1000
```
proxysql> select hostgroup_id, hostname, weight from runtime_mysql_servers;
+--------------+----------+--------+
| hostgroup_id | hostname | weight |
+--------------+----------+--------+
| 2            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 2            | mysql2   | 1000   |
| 2            | mysql3   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql2   | 1000   |
| 3            | mysql3   | 1000   |
| 4            | mysql1   | 1000   |
| 4            | mysql2   | 1000   |
+--------------+----------+--------+
8 rows in set (0.01 sec)
```

If we empty mysql_galera_hostgroups table and repeat the test, the weight is not affected.

issue.title: [Feat.Req.] ProxySQL as an authentication middleware (separate credentials for frontend and backend)
issue.body:
I would like to use _ProxySQL_ as an auth middleware/proxy for MySQL server.
To my understanding, _ProxySQL_ currently reuses the credentials it received from the client to connect to the backend server, I would need to have it's own list of credentials to accept connections from AND it's own list of credentials to use when connecting to a backend.

The need: Delegate authentication to a MySQL server/database to another brick (thus. _ProxySQL_).

I want my users to auth themselves on the middleware/proxy (_ProxySQL_) using it's own local users database (or an external auth such as LDAP, PAM, etc.) which will then connect to the real MySQL server (the backend) associated to the user using the backend's credentials.

Schema:

```

                 +---------------+    +-------------+
                 |users2hostgroup|    |mysql_servers|
                 +---------------+    +-------------+
                                ^      ^
                                |      |                         +-----------------------+
                             (3)|      |(5)                      |db1.app-foo.example.com|
                                |      |                         +-----------------------+
                                v      v(4)
+------------+        (1)      +--------+          (6)           +-----------------------+
|MySQL client|---------------->|ProxySQL|----------------------->|db2.app-foo.example.com|
+------------+                 +--------+                        +-----------------------+
                                  ^       
                                  |                              +----------------------+
                               (2)|                              |db.app-bar.example.com|
                                  |                              +----------------------+
                                  v
                              +-----------+
                              |mysql_users|
                              +-----------+
```

Steps:

1. Client opens connection to _ProxySQL_ using credentials `bob_foo:secretB1`
2. _ProxySQL_ authenticates the user by validating the provided credentials from step 1. with it's `mysql_users` table (=> `user_id=2`).
   (If credentials from step 1. are not OK: _ProxySQL_ refuses connection. If they are OK, continue)
3. _ProxySQL_ checks the `users2hostgroup` table to determine which group of MySQL servers the user from step 1. has access to (=> `hostgroup_id=1`).
4. _ProxySQL_ looks into `mysql_group_replication_hostgroups` and `mysql_servers` to determine the MySQL server to connect to (classic process) (=> `hostname=db2.app-foo.example.com`).
5. _ProxySQL_ retrieves from the `mysql_servers` table the credentials to connect with (=> `app-foo:secretF`).
6. _ProxySQL_ connects to determined MySQL server (step 4.) using the credentials found in step 5.

Table `mysql_users`:

| id | login | password |
|----|-------|----------|
| 1  | alice | secretA  |
| 2  | bob_foo   | secretB1  |
| 3  | bob_bar   | secretB2  |

Table `users2hostgroup`:

| user_id | hostgroup_id |
|------|-----------|
| 1    | 1         |
| 2    | 1         |
| 3    | 2         |


Table `mysql_servers`:

| hostgroup_id | hostname                | port | login   | password |
|--------------|-------------------------|------|---------|----------|
| 1            | db1.app-foo.example.com | 3306 | app-foo | secretF|
| 1            | db2.app-foo.example.com | 3306 | app-foo | secretF|
| 2            | db.app-bar.example.com  | 3306 | app-bar | secretB|

comment.body: I really hope to see this functionality being added because I cannot use replicas with ProxySQL connectend to Azure MariaDB.
